awd_titl_txt: CEDAR: Global and Seasonal Occurrence and Characteristics of Mesospheric Bores
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is an experimental effort to characterize rare but strong disturbances in the Earth's atmosphere that are often visible to the naked eye as large bands of faint optical emission called airglow that extend from horizon to horizon. These disturbances are atmospheric waves that are known as mesospheric bores. These waves are characterized by an extensive propagating "step-like" frontal region of enhanced or depleted airglow followed a train of waves. Mesospheric bores exhibit large brightness amplitudes (typically >10%) and can transport large amounts of energy and momentum through the mesosphere-lower-thermosphere (MLT) region. The wave dynamics significantly affects the large-scale temperature and circulation structure of the MLT and higher atmospheric regions. Understanding the full scope of wave effects on the MLT region is important for obtaining a complete physical picture of atmospheric processes. 

This work will utilize the data from eight existing ground-based optical imaging systems, together with a suite of co-located multi-diagnostic instrumentation and satellite data, to investigate the global and seasonal occurrence characteristics of mesospheric bores and other frontal gravity waves in the MLT region. The effort will:
1) conduct a global survey and characterization of these waves and an estimate of the momentum flux contributing to the MLT using the Boston University all-sky imager network, and
2) utilize co-located ground-based multi-diagnostic measurements and satellite measurements to supplement the imager data in order to fully characterize both the propagation environment and the gravity wave propagation modes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was the first comprehensive global study of the occurrence of mesospheric bores. The major goals of the project were to:(i) Investigate the occurrence and characteristics of mesospheric bores in a global context. (ii) Investigate the seasonal variations in bore occurrence at each site.(iii) Compare bore occurrence and seasonal variations between locations. 
Mesospheric bores are a recently discovered type of wave disturbance in the Earth’s upper atmosphere, known as mesospheric bores. They are large-amplitude waves (~1 km high) that propagate through the atmosphere at the edge of space, in the 80 to 100 km altitude region. Their origins are, as yet, unknown. They are considered important because they carry large amounts of energy – typically more than 10 times what ordinary atmospheric waves carry. Ordinary atmospheric waves, known as gravity waves, originate from storms and other weather systems in the lower atmosphere. They then travel outwards and upwards like ripples on a pond and, upon reaching the upper atmosphere, they break in a similar way to the rolling breakers on a beach. That deposited wave energy can do a couple of things; either mix and heat the atmosphere or speed up or slow down the local wind flow. The latter has important consequences for understanding global-scale wind circulation patterns because such wave behavior needs to be accounted for. Unfortunately, the amount of gravity wave energy deposited into the upper atmosphere is poorly known. It is also quite variable both regionally and seasonally.  

The project yielded several major findings: 

1. At all sites investigated, the annual occurrence of mesospheric bores was relatively constant throughout the year with perhaps an increase at the end of the year. In terms of propagation direction, a strong seasonal variation was observed at most of the sites, and marked differences in direction between the sites. The finding suggests either a dependence on the seasonal stratospheric wind variations or seasonal variations in source(s) responsible for bore formation.

2. The mean lifetime of a bore event was 3–3.5 hours (σ = 0.4 hrs), a finding that was consistent between all the sites. The monthly variation in lifetime was also independent of season. Both findings suggest a limit to the amount of energy associated with a bore event.

3. The local transit time of a bore passing through zenith at any of the sites was similar and, on monthly time-scales, occurred at ~1 hour after local midnight. The effect was also independent of season.

4. The consistency of the effect and the high occurrence rate of bores on consecutive nights suggest strongly that the tidal wind structure is important factor in bore occurrence. 

5. There was a relatively high rate of occurrence of multiple bore events during a night at any particular site – a surprising finding for a phenomenon with a seemingly low occurrence. Multiple bores – events with two or more bores exhibiting similar propagation azimuths, speeds, and scale-sizes – occurred 1–2 days per month (mean = 1.4 events month-1; σ = 0.3 events month-1). 

This project is the first large-scale global investigation of mesospheric bores, a nonlinear type of gravity wave disturbance. Their occurrence is poorly understood but they are important because they can transport large amounts of energy and momentum large distances with little attenuation. Global circulation models are, as yet, unable to resolve these small-scale disturbances. A more accurate accounting of the amounts a wave energy being transported into and through the MLT region, on a global and seasonal level, is essential for a fuller understanding of the upper atmosphere and its variability.
